description: See the etymology of the corresponding lemma form.

examples: The hanging vines made the house look older than it was.

entries.meaning: (chess, of a piece) Unprotected and exposed to capture.
(baseball, slang, of an off-speed pitch) Hittable; poorly executed by the pitcher, hence relatively easy to hit.
(UK, slang, of a person, originally Manchester) Ugly; very unattractive; disgusting.
examples: MUGSEY: Yeah. You fancy ‘im don’ you.LEANNE: No I don’t. Shut yer mouth.MUGSEY: Your mum said he’s gonna end up just like his dad.LEANNE: She don’ even know Bingo. Anyway, I don’t fancy ‘im, ‘e’s hanging.

description: From Middle English hangynge, honginge, equivalent to hang +‎ -ing. Compare Old English hengen (“hanging”) and hōhing (“hanging”).

entries.meaning: (countable, uncountable) The act of hanging a person (or oneself) by the neck in order to kill that person (or to commit suicide).
examples: Hanging is the punishment for one convicted of war crimes, there.
The hanging of the bandits was attended by the whole village.

entries.meaning: (countable) Anything that is hung as a decorative element (such as curtains, gobelins, or posters).
examples: The various hangings on that Christmas tree look nice.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The way in which hangings (decorations) are arranged.
examples: I dislike the cramped hanging in the gallery of 18th century painters.
